Issues.Title: fix(core): Discard self-imports on standalone components.
Issues.Body:
Before this fix, a self import would define the component twice in the `directiveRegistry` which would then fire a `NG0300` when compiled with the JIT.

fixes #50525
Note: #50554 also fixes #50525, there were two issues in one. 

- [x] Bugfix

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(core): Discard self-imports on standalone components." (#50557)

Issues.Title: fix(core): incorrectly throwing error for self-referencing component
Issues.Body:
Components are implied to be self-referencing, but if they explicitly set themselves in the `imports` array, they would throw an error because we weren't filtering them out.

Fixes #50525.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(core): incorrectly throwing error for self-referencing component" (#50559)

Issues.Title: fix(zone.js): patch entire promise in node
Issues.Body:
In https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/49144 we introduced a change to only patch `Promise.prototype.then` due to Node.js `SafePromise` complaining about `Promise.prototype.then` called on incompatible receiver. This however introduced a number of regressions. This commit reverts this change and re-introduces the changes to patch the entire promise on Node.

The original `SafePromise` problem is no longer reproducible as of Node.js version 18.13+ as it was addressed as part of https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/45175.

While the Angular CLI does not yet generate ESM server bundles, users using ESM with dynamic imports will require using Node.js 18.13 or later.

Closes #50513, closes #50457, closes #50414 and closes #49930
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(zone.js): patch entire promise in node" (#50552)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler-cli): fix incremental compilation breaking when running compiler through closure
Issues.Body:
If the compiler CLI is running through closure compiler, the trait decorator handlers are converted
from classes to functions as ES5 is picked as default output target for the bundled version.

The problem is that currently all trait handlers end up having the same `name`. i.e. an empty string,
and therefore adopting previous traits from a previous build iteration result in the incorrect handler
being used for e.g. registrering, compiling etc- causing ambiguous/confusing errors down the line in other parts.

We can look into changing the output target in the future, but even then we are safer using an
actual literal due to property renaming.

```js
const $$closure$$NgModuleDecoratorHandler = function() {}
```

It is is questionable if we should just simply NOT run the compiler
through JSCompiler.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(compiler-cli): fix incremental compilation breaking when running compiler through closure" (#50553)

Issues.Title: feat(devtools): add total time for a component type during a change detection run
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

common

### Description

NIT: There's no devtools in the selections for a feature requests so I choose common 😬.

Seeing the time it takes for a component where it's used during a change detection is great, there are cases where we want to see the total time for all the component instances during a change detection run. 

Would a feature like this make sense for general usage? And should I send a PR with my changes? 
If yes, what would be the suggested way to go forward (UX wise)? 

### Proposed solution

Having a table or a filtered table where we can select the component type and where we can see the total time of all the component instances would be great. 

This is needed in cases we want to enable change detection on push or when optimizing the performance of a component and this way we can easily see how we improve the change detection cycle time. 

In the example below I've updated the devtools code to add the total time for all the directives in that CD run. 

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/25394362/f083a41f-8e63-47c4-aaac-0dffb76f097b)


### Alternatives considered

Sum the total of all component instances times one by one by selecting them in the graph.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(devtools): add total time for a component type during a change detection run" (#50555)

Issues.Title: Fails to bindInput in time for SSR to use the input for api's
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

platform-browser, platform-server, Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

So just using the barebones implementation of angular with SSR and using `withComponentInputBinding` with a routing config like:

```ts
{
    path: ':id',
    loadComponent: () => import('./home/home.component'),
}
```

And inside the component to look like this

```ts
@Component({
  selector: 'app-home',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [CommonModule],
  templateUrl: './home.component.html',
  styleUrls: ['./home.component.scss'],
  changeDetection: ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush
})
export default class HomeComponent {
  @Input({ required: true }) id!: string;

  title = 'hello world signals';
  $content = toSignal(this.http.get(`${environment.baseUrl}/content/item/${this.id}`));

  constructor(private http: HttpClient) {}
}
```

Here I try to basically use the id which is bound to the component in my service call on the component to avoid using those ngOnInit or Input() set()...

To simplify my code

Note its actually available 

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/sp90/phantom

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
To start:

1. `npm run api`
2. `npm run dev:ssr`
3. `localhost:4202/123`

It returns undefined but should return the id (123) passed in the url
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.0.3
Node: 20.0.0 (Unsupported)
Package Manager: npm 9.6.4
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 16.0.3
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server
... router
```


### Anything else?

So worth noting is that the input is rendered by the server if put in the template so its something about execution order
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Fails to bindInput in time for SSR to use the input for api's" (#50550)

Issues.Title: Audit usage of navigator.userAgent, navigator.appVersion, and navigator.platform
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

zone.js

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

This is getting really, really nitpicky but I am trying to keep our code base very clean.

Strong linting rules, style guidelines, acccessability and no browser errors/breaking changes/improvement notifications.

Due to what [seems to be this line of code](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/c3205d0962f1ff0d2dd4fa26c70372f6fe80f5e3/packages/zone.js/lib/common/utils.ts#L489-L515) in zone.js, Chrome warns on:

> Audit usage of navigator.userAgent, navigator.appVersion, and navigator.platform

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/18640860/104664a8-f3df-45cb-9fcb-b9fc3cb0036d)

Is it possible to update zone.js in any way so as to not check `navigator.userAgent` and avoid this?

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

Any Angular site using zone.js using Chrome

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
Audit usage of navigator.userAgent, navigator.appVersion, and navigator.platform

A page or script is accessing at least one of navigator.userAgent, navigator.appVersion, and navigator.platform. Starting in Chrome 101, the amount of information available in the User Agent string will be reduced.

To fix this issue, replace the usage of navigator.userAgent, navigator.appVersion, and navigator.platform with feature detection, progressive enhancement, or migrate to navigator.userAgentData.

Note that for performance reasons, only the first access to one of the properties is shown.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

So it looks the like this if 'abc' is the template content received from server `abc` during hydration `abc abc` <-- this looks sometimes a bit ugly after hydration `abc` So is it possible that the passed template gets just once rendered during the hydration process? template

Issues.Title: Detached elements stay in memory when animated
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

animations

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

If you use an animation on the element and toggle it with ngIf, it seems to be staying in the memory according to Detached Elements debugger in Edge. On a brief look it appears that maybe a WeakMap has to be used some place instead of Map:

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/11832552/a5097c70-d9fa-41ec-a6e2-52dca1d86b10)


### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-vnp1kv

1. Open this link in Edge browser
2. Open DevTools -> Detached Elements tab
3. Select the correct frame in the dropdown on that tab (it should say `https://stackblitz-starters-vnp1kv.stackblitz.io/`)
4. Toggle element a few times with the button
5. Press get detached element
6. Press analyze to see what keeps the elements there (you will see the above screenshot)

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
Multiple copies of DOM element stay in memory.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
I noticed it in Angular 12, but it is reproducible in 16 as well, see linked StackBlitz
```


### Anything else?

An article I learned about Detached Elements from:
https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2021/12/09/debug-memory-leaks-detached-elements-tool-devtools/
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Detached elements stay in memory when animated" (#50533)

Issues.Title: The ability to resolve SASS using the library namespace in workspace projects
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

Issues.Title: APIs for authoring bootstrap-agnostic ng add schematics
Issues.Body:
These changes add the necessary APIs that library authors can use to create `ng add` schematics that don't need to account for whether a project is NgModule-based or standalone. They're split up across a few commits to make reviewing easier. High-level description of the commits:

1. `refactor(@schematics/angular): allow for imports to be inserted under an alias` - Expands the `insertImport` utility to allow for aliases to be specified. This is necessary to avoid naming conflicts when automatically adding imports. I've also added some tests for `insertImport` since it didn't have any test coverage.
2. `refactor(@schematics/angular): add utility to find top-level identifiers` - Adds a utility that can be used to find whether a file has a top-level identifier with a specific name. Useful when trying to avoid import conflicts.
3. `feat(@schematics/angular): add bootstrap-agnostic utilities for writing ng-add schematics` - This is the commit that adds the two new `addRootImport` and `addRootProvider` utilities that library authors can use.
4. `refactor(@schematics/angular): deprecate private standalone utilities` - Marks the existing private standalone utilities as deprecated in favor of the new ones.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "APIs for authoring bootstrap-agnostic ng add schematics" (#25309)

Issues.Title: node_path not working with angular cli
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

We can't check in our node modules in our build gitlab based on company policy they are much too large.
When node_modules are in the project folder ng build works 
When node modules are in a parent directory ng build works 
When we move node_modules to a different folder and set set NODE_PATH=D:\henryNodeModules\node_modules
We get error node_modules cannot be found for example 
 Cannot find module '@angular/core' or its corresponding type declarations.
Noticed previous similar issue :
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/3864

Any workarounds fixes

Do any ngbuild and move node_modules

Issues.Title: jest in v16 is not working in multiple project
Issues.Body:
### Is this a bug report or a feature request?

- [X] Bug Report
- [ ] Feature Request

### Please provide the steps to reproduce the issue [Bug Report only]

Sample repository is in git@github.com:sangb-han/angv16_multi.git . 

Create project like followings 
```bash
> ng new angv16_multi --no-create-application
> cd angv16_multi
> ng g project sample_app
> ng g library sample 
```

After that, jest has been configured like in angular blog. 

If I ran in workspace with single project, there was no problem. 
But in workspace with multiple project, test with jest failed. 


### Please provide the expected behavior vs the actual behavior you encountered [Bug Report only]

All test run successfully. 

### Please provide a screenshot if possible [Bug Report only]

```bash
ged:angv16_multi% ng test 
Node.js version v19.8.1 detected.
Odd numbered Node.js versions will not enter LTS status and should not be used for production. For more information, please see https://nodejs.org/en/about/releases/.

Issues.Title: Application code is not being 'up-targeted' to ES2022 despite warning message from CLI
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The following message is shown by the CLI if changing `target` to ES2015 for Angular 15 +

> TypeScript compiler options "target" and "useDefineForClassFields" are set to "ES2022" and "false" respectively by the Angular CLI. To control ECMA version and features use the Browerslist configuration. For more information, see https://angular.io/guide/build#configuring-browser-compatibility NOTE: You can set the "target" to "ES2022" in the project's tsconfig to remove this warning.

However code running in the browser using `??` (a pre ES2022 feature) is still transpiled, even without any changes to Browserslist.

Either there is a bug, or the message needs to be rewritten to be clearer as to what is really happening.

See also: [commit](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/23936/commits/cdac700b93d5593ce92b44b1691941673eaf25b0#diff-2d55449c69797885b38f6b957a1fd03d27beda366a9270293719ec041cf15d0f)  for #23936 by @alan-agius4 


### Minimal Reproduction

// 16.0.3
Run `ng new project-name`    

Update tsconfig.json to

```
compilerOptions: {
   "target": "ES2015"
}
```

Add the following line of code to AppComponent.ts:

    person = null ?? { name: 'Simon' };`

Run `ng serve`

View `main.js` in browser and observe that the code has been transpiled:

    this.person = false ? 0 : {
        name: 'Simon'
    };

With `target` set to `ES2022` the `??` remains:

    this.person = null ?? {
        name: 'Simon'
    };


### Exception or Error

```text
The code is still being transpiled, despite the warning message telling me it has been up-targeted to ES2022.
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 16.0.3
Node: 18.14.0
Package Manager: npm 9.3.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 16.0.3
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1600.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.0.3
@angular-devkit/core            16.0.3
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.0.3
@schematics/angular             16.0.3
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.0.4
```


### Anything else relevant?

This is similar to https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/24435, but that is related to `useDefineForClassFields` and not `target`.

See my answer here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/75047760/typescript-target-warnings-after-angular-15-update/76369523#76369523

The main reason this is an issue is because you can observe your user code is transpiled, but Angular / vendor code is not - which may lead to a false sense of security if needing to target older browsers.

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use fast-glob for file searching support
Issues.Body: The file searching within the build system (both Webpack and esbuild) now use the `fast-glob` package for globbing which provides a small performance improvement. Since the assets option in particular is within the critical path of the buil pipeline, the performance benefit from the switch will be most prevalent in asset heavy projects. As an example, the Angular Material documentation site saw the asset discovery time reduced by over half with the switch. `fast-glob` is also the package used by Vite which provides additional benefit by ensuring that the Angular CLI behavior matches that of the newly integrated Vite development server.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use fast-glob for file searching support" (#25297)

Issues.Title: [16.0.x] fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): preemptively remove AOT metadata in esbuild builder
Issues.Body:
The Angular compiler generates two types of metadata calls when it generates AOT code. This metadata is not used in fully AOT compiled applications and can contain direct references to components, services, etc. that may affect the output chunk layout of the application. While this currently has not lead to any problems, it could in the future and the Webpack bundler already performs a transform that preemptively removes these calls. To remain consistent, the esbuild-based build system will now also perform this transform.

This also updates the autoprefixer behavior tests to check the actual runtime style text instead of the style text within the metadata calls.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[16.0.x] fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): preemptively remove AOT metadata in esbuild builder" (#25295)

To remain consistent, the esbuild-based build system will now also perform this transform.

Issues.Title: Tree shaking: unused code remains in productive app
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Hi,
I tried to upgrade from angular 15 to 16.0.3. The application works fine without the "optimization" flag set to true in the angular.json file. But when set to true, some code remains in the main....js that causes an error, when the page gets loaded.
The console log states "main.bc110eb6fa951c13.js:1 Uncaught ReferenceError: hd is not defined". 
Here is the part of the code, that causes this issue:

`class EP extends hd {
...
}
`

After some investigation (and also turning off the optimization flag), I found out that this code originally looked like that:

`
class ReferenceExpr extends ExpressionBase {
...
}
`

So the ExpressionBase class is missing. Which is also fine, I guess, since it is not used in the code and hence was removed by tree shaking. Also the ReferenceExpr class is, as far as I can tell, not used in the code. When I search for a usage of the class "EP" in the optimised code, there is no location where I could find it. 

Version 15.2.4 worked without any issues. Did I miss anything in the upgrade process, or is it a bug in the build optimisation?


### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
main.1dde1c799c90e486.js:1 Uncaught ReferenceError: hd is not defined
    at 83 (main.1dde1c799c90e486.js:1:290279)
    at a (runtime.de42e30e1a22c589.js:1:143)
    at main.1dde1c799c90e486.js:1:4227714
    at n (runtime.de42e30e1a22c589.js:1:951)
    at main.1dde1c799c90e486.js:1:55
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

Issues.Title: Implement vendor chunk support for esbuild builder
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

### Description

When using esbuild builder, we got many chunks: 

![IMG_20230527_000313_004](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/17675259/9be85a3e-dd78-423e-b7ed-0161a972aae4)

but that amount (we have around 50-65) not suitable for production use cases, because of performance application degradation due to poor web vitals. That happens due to absence of vendor chunk support. Yes we got that message, when we 'serve' app:

```
The esbuild-based browser application builder ('browser-esbuild') is currently in developer preview and is not yet recommended for production use. For additional information, please see https://angular.io/guide/esbuild
The 'namedChunks' option is not used by this builder and will be ignored.
The 'vendorChunk' option is not used by this builder and will be ignored.
```


### Describe the solution you'd like

Would be good to have support of vendor chunk when all node modules libs concatenated like webpack builder do.

That dramatically changed core web vitals due to small amount of initial chunks

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Implement vendor chunk support for esbuild builder" (#25283)

Issues.Title: Generate command should respect file name safety conventions.
Issues.Body:
### Command

generate

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Long story short is that the Angular CLI generate or g command is capable of doing some illegal and difficult to reverse file operations.

Longer version: I was going to create a component this morning to make building PrimeNG p-tables simpler and more dynamic. At the time I started, what I was thinking of was specific to a set of tables I intended to use in an administrative context, so I navigated to something like /src/modules/sales/costing-tool/components/templates and typed "ng g c admin-table". 

Before I hit enter, I thought about it and decided that rather than creating a module and specific use component that I'd rather make a general use component for generating p-tables dynamically & that it belonged in a shared module rather than a feature module. I thought I'd already deleted the CLI command out of the terminal so without looking I typed cd.. and hit enter. Which was the beginning of a 2+ hour headache that ended up costing me 2 days of work and which potentially could've cost me all the work I've done since May 5. 

So the command I effectively entered was "ng g c admin-tablecd..", and what happened is that the CLI was able to somehow dodge the OS level naming safety conventions & it created a folder named admin-tablecd.., which caused there to be an unresolvable reference in my project structure and made it unloadable and unbuildable. And there was nothing I could do to delete the offending folder. I tried deleting it through the UI, using DOS commands, using WSL commands including rmdir with the -rf flag, nothing would get rid of it, even after a reboot. I had just about resolved myself to having to clone my latest remote to a new local repo which would've set me back to the 5th when I tried rmdir with the "\\?\c:\path\to\bad\directory" syntax which finally worked.

I think that optimally the generate command should respect naming safety conventions, or minimally provide a complimentary command to remove generated components. 

### Minimal Reproduction

Via the CLI, generate a component with a name that ends in a directory traversal operator, i.e. new-componentcd..

### Exception or Error

```text
The system cannot find the file or directory specified
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular:

Package                      Version
------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect    0.1502.4
@angular-devkit/core         15.2.4
@angular-devkit/schematics   15.2.4
@schematics/angular          15.2.4
```


### Anything else relevant?

Can't think of anything.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Generate command should respect file name safety conventions." (#25282)

Issues.Title: bug(datepicker): NVDA announces entire week of dates when dialog opens
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Posting for our team's accessibility expert:

Our accessibility expert found that in NVDA 2023.1, when a user opens the datepicker dialog, the screen reader announces the entire next week of dates from the focus date. 
**We did not observe this behavior with JAWS 2023 or VoiceOver on MacOS 13.4.**

Related, turning off the default "Automatic Say All on Page Load" setting in NVDA (under Preferences > Browse Mode) does "remedy" the issue. However, our accessibility team is wary of asking users to change a default setting in NVDA for this.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/ahmyck
Steps to reproduce:
1. Click into the date field
2. Tab over to the dialog-open button
3. Hit enter and listen to the entire screen reader output (or check something like Speech Viewer for NVDA)

Notice the announcement of the entire next week of dates.

### Expected Behavior

Expected less verbosity and for only the focused date/cell to be announced.


### Actual Behavior

Currently, the entire next week of dates will be announced by the screen reader after the currently focused cell.

NVDA 2023.1 output (italics indicate unexpected readout):
> Choose a date  dialog
> table
> June 2, 2023  row 3  Friday  column 6
> table  with 7 rows and 7 columns  clickable  row 3  Friday  column 6  June 2, 2023  toggle button  not pressed    current date
> Choose a date
> toggle button  not pressed    current date  June 2, 2023
> _Saturday  column 7  toggle button  not pressed    June 3, 2023_
> _row 4  Sunday  column 1  toggle button  not pressed    June 4, 2023_
> _Monday  column 2  toggle button  not pressed    June 5, 2023_
> _Tuesday  column 3  toggle button  not pressed    June 6, 2023_
> _Wednesday  column 4  toggle button  not pressed    June 7, 2023_
> _Thursday  column 5  toggle button  not pressed    June 8, 2023_
> _Friday  column 6  toggle button  not pressed    June 9, 2023_
> _Saturday  column 7  toggle button  not pressed    June 10, 2023_
> _row 5  Sunday  column 1  toggle button  not pressed    June 11, 2023_

### Environment

- Angular: 13.x, 14.x, 15.x, 16.x
- CDK/Material: 13.x, 14.x, 15.x, 16.x
- Browser(s): Chrome (114), Firefox (112) 
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10, Windows 11
- Screen readers: NVDA 2023.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(datepicker): NVDA announces entire week of dates when dialog opens" (#27228)

Issues.Title: bug(slider): Right click on a slider makes it permanently focused and unresponsive
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The issue consists of two parts:
- The focus ripple stays forever after a right click. This equally applies to one-handle and two-handle sliders
- Two-handle slider only: right click on a handle makes the other handle broken - it no longer responds to mouse events, cannot be clicked/dragged

Reproduced in v15 and v16

### Reproduction

Use the examples from the docs: https://material.angular.io/components/slider/overview#selecting-a-range
Steps to reproduce:
1. Right-click on a range (two-handle) slider. It will mark one handle as focused (ripple is displayed)
2. Close the context menu (by clicking outside)
3. Click anywhere else on the page, including other focusable elements
4. Go back to the focused slider and try to drag the other handle (which is currently not focused)


### Expected Behavior

- After (3), the focus ripple disappears from the slider.
- In (4), you can normally click/drag the slider handle

### Actual Behavior

- The slider's handle remains focused no matter what you do with the rest of the page.
- The other handle of the slider does not react to click/drag. Its interactivity only gets restored after I click on the focused handle one more time.

### Environment

- Angular: 16
- CDK/Material: 16
- Browser(s): Firefox, Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(slider): Right click on a slider makes it permanently focused and unresponsive" (#27225)

Issues.Title: bug(@angular/material): Style doesn't build with yarn pnp
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

As reported in #24128 and maybe fixed in #24536 using yarn in pnp mode means, that there is no predefined path-relation between @angular/material and @angular/cdk. Still https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/material/_theming.scss (and others) user relative paths to access cdk-files and `@forward` them.

I realize, that there is a test-case specifically for this (https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/integration/yarn-pnp-compat/), but it may be just not fully test the situation as it uses `"@angular/cdk": "file:../../dist/releases/cdk"` and `"@angular/material": "file:../../dist/releases/material",` in https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/integration/yarn-pnp-compat/package.json, thus keeping the path relation between @angular/material and @angular/cdk.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1.  Go to a local copy of https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/integration/yarn-pnp-compat/
2. Change `package.json` to e.g. reference `"@angular/cdk": "^16.0.3"` and `"@angular/material": "^16.0.3"`
3. Run `yarn install`
4. Add `@import '@angular/material/theming';` as second line to `src/styles.scss`
5. Run `yarn run build`


### Expected Behavior

This should build

### Actual Behavior

```text
❯ yarn run build
Workspace extension with invalid name (defaultProject) found.
⠋ Generating browser application bundles (phase: setup)...    TypeScript compiler options "target" and "useDefineForClassFields" are set to "ES2022" and "false" respectively by the Angular CLI. To control ECMA version and features use the Browerslist configuration. For more information, see https://angular.io/guide/build#configuring-browser-compatibility
    NOTE: You can set the "target" to "ES2022" in the project's tsconfig to remove this warning.
✔ Browser application bundle generation complete.

./src/styles.scss - Error: Module build failed (from ./.yarn/__virtual__/sass-loader-virtual-7addf34da3/0/cache/sass-loader-npm-13.2.2-b5bbed2dce-0368e4eaa4.zip/node_modules/sass-loader/dist/cjs.js):
SassError: Can't find stylesheet to import.
  ╷
5 │ @forward '../cdk/a11y/index.import';
  │ ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  ╵
  @angular\material\_theming.scss 5:1  @import
  src\styles.scss 2:9                  root stylesheet

./src/styles.scss?ngGlobalStyle - Error: Module build failed (from ./.yarn/__virtual__/mini-css-extract-plugin-virtual-c5c86c3c0c/0/cache/mini-css-extract-plugin-npm-2.7.5-7e01d66430-afc37cdfb7.zip/node_modules/mini-css-extract-plugin/dist/loader.js):
HookWebpackError: Module build failed (from ./.yarn/__virtual__/sass-loader-virtual-7addf34da3/0/cache/sass-loader-npm-13.2.2-b5bbed2dce-0368e4eaa4.zip/node_modules/sass-loader/dist/cjs.js):
SassError: Can't find stylesheet to import.
  ╷
5 │ @forward '../cdk/a11y/index.import';
  │ ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  ╵
  @angular\material\_theming.scss 5:1  @import
  src\styles.scss 2:9                  root stylesheet
```

- CDK/Material: 16.0.3
- Browser(s): -

Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description When clicking/ dragging the slider thumbs it sometimes results in the track getting one step behind the thumb. It's quite easy to see if the steps of the slider are large enough (e.g. min=0 max=9 step=1). I could only reproduce it when interacting with different thumbs each time: e.g. first, interact with the "start" thumb, then interact with the "end" thumb. Move the start thumb to the next position 2. Move the end thumb to a new position Repeating the two steps until the issue is reproduced ### Expected Behavior The track is always aligned with the thumbs position ### Actual Behavior Occasionally, the track stays one step behind Screenshots: ### Environment - Angular: 16 - CDK/Material: 16 - Browser(s): Firefox, Chrome - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS

Issues.Title: bug(mat-tab-nav-bar): mat-tab-nav-bar does not use "stretchTabs" from the MAT_TABS_CONFIG
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The tabs docs state that MAT_TABS_CONFIG "can be used to configure the default options for the tabs module". After providing a config with `stretchTabs: false`, the component does not disable stretching. Disabling stretching through a binding works. Source inspection indicates that mat-tab-nav-bar does not use MAT_TABS_CONFIG for `stretchTabs` at all, unlike the tab-group.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/749enw?file=src%2Fexample%2Ftab-nav-bar-basic-example.ts
Steps to reproduce:
Add the provider:
```ts
{
provide: MAT_TABS_CONFIG,
useValue: { stretchTabs: false },
}
```


### Expected Behavior

The `stretchTabs` from the provided config is applied

### Actual Behavior

The `stretchTabs` from the provided config is not applied

### Environment

- Angular: 16.0.3
- CDK/Material: 16.0.2
- Browser(s): Chrome 113
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 11

Issues.Title: bug(slider): Using a slider with a formControl breaks change detection
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

I have a widget that uses `mat-slider`. This widget takes a value as an input and sets it to the form control bound to the slider:
```
// template
<mat-slider>
  <input matSliderThumb [formControl]="sliderValue">
</>

// component
@Input() value: number

sliderValue = new FormControl(0, {nonNullable: true})

ngOnChanges() {
  this.sliderValue.setValue(this.value) // <-- this

  // derived value used in the template
  this.isDefaultValue = this.value === 0
}
```

Looks like the `.setValue` call breaks change detection. The `isDefaultValue` value is properly derived (as per console.log output), but is not reflected in HTML. It will get updated after the next interaction with the widget (which triggers change detection), or after manually calling `changeDetectorRef.detectChanges()`.

This happens with a single-handle or a two-handle slider.

It only happens when the value is bound to the slider via a form control. If I pass the value as a property binding instead (`[value]="sliderValue.value"`), everything works fine.
Also moving the `isDefaultValue` calculation up to be before the `.setValue` call magically solves it, too.

![slider-cd](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/1004015/476b5b2b-d1dd-4329-9c82-337bbc344dd7)

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/xsoedg?file=src%2Fexample%2Fapp-widget.component.ts
1. Click the "set to 2" button

### Expected Behavior

- Slider value is printed as "2"
- Slider default state is printed as "false"
- The slider turns blue

### Actual Behavior

- Slider value is printed as "2" (correct)
- Slider default state is printed as "true" (incorrect)
- The slider remains gray (incorrect)

### Environment

- Angular: 16
- CDK/Material: 16
- Browser(s): Firefox, Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(slider): Using a slider with a formControl breaks change detection" (#27217)

Issues.Title: Conflict in dependency resolution when installing @angular/cdk@16.0.2
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

@angular/common 15

### Description

I am experiencing a dependency conflict while trying to install @angular/cdk@16.0.2 in an Angular project. The project currently has the following dependencies:

`"dependencies": {
    "@angular/animations": "^16.1.0-next.2",
    "@angular/common": "^16.1.0-next.2",
    "@angular/compiler": "^16.1.0-next.2",
    "@angular/core": "^16.1.0-next.2",
    "@angular/forms": "^16.1.0-next.2",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "^16.1.0-next.2",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "^16.1.0-next.2",
    "@angular/router": "^16.1.0-next.2",
    "rxjs": "~7.8.0",
    "tslib": "^2.3.0",
    "zone.js": "~0.13.0"
}
`
When I try to install @angular/cdk using the command ng add @angular/cdk@16.0.2, I receive the following error:

`The package @angular/cdk@16.0.2 will be installed and executed.
Would you like to proceed? Yes
npm ERR! code ERESOLVE
npm ERR! ERESOLVE unable to resolve dependency tree
npm ERR!
npm ERR! While resolving: game@0.0.0
npm ERR! Found: @angular/common@16.1.0-next.2
npm ERR! node_modules/@angular/common
npm ERR!   @angular/common@"^16.1.0-next.2" from the root project
npm ERR!
npm ERR! Could not resolve dependency:
npm ERR! peer @angular/common@"^16.0.0 || ^17.0.0" from @angular/cdk@16.0.2
npm ERR! node_modules/@angular/cdk
npm ERR!   @angular/cdk@"16.0.2" from the root project
npm ERR!
npm ERR! Fix the upstream dependency conflict, or retry
npm ERR! this command with --force or --legacy-peer-deps
npm ERR! to accept an incorrect (and potentially broken) dependency resolution.`

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create an Angular project.
2. Run the command `ng add  @angular/cdk`.
3. Run the command `npm update`.
4. Run the command `npm install`.
5. Run the command `ng add @angular/cdk --legacy-peer-deps`
6. Run the command `ng add @angular/cdk --force`.




### Expected Behavior

I expect @angular/cdk@16.0.2 to be installed without any dependency conflicts, considering the specified versions of the other Angular dependencies.

### Actual Behavior

The installation fails with the error message mentioned above.

### Environment

- Angular: ^16.1.0-next.2
- CDK/Material:   @angular/cdk@"16.0.2
- Browser(s): N/A
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Conflict in dependency resolution when installing @angular/cdk@16.0.2" (#27203)

Issues.Title: bug(ripple): all nested matRipple ancestors get launched, not only the the closest one
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.2.7

### Description

There is already a locked bug (#26656), but I would like to approach from a different point.

In angular/components v14 the ripple event management was different, probably not delegated, but mainly it was using the bubble phase of events. with v15 this was changed and using global delegation causes all the ancestor ripples to fire.

The fact that ripple is now using the capture phase makes it worse, cause it is virtually impossible for the developer to stop/control these events to avoid the aforementioned ancestor ripple cascade.

By chaning the RippleEventManager::_delegateEventHandler (and optionally adding a boolean return value to the ripple event handlers) this issue could be easily mitigated.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz-starters-gbsh9b.stackblitz.io
Steps to reproduce:
1. click on any of the buttons
2. see how the ripple get fired both on the button and the card


### Expected Behavior

Ripple should be handled by the ripple renderer closest to the event target.
The event should either be swallowed by the first handler or in case it is disabled the next closest handler should be called, etc.

### Actual Behavior

All ripple renderers that contain the event target will be launched at the same time.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.0.3
- CDK/Material: 16.0.2
- Browser(s): Chrome 113.0.5672.127
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(ripple): all nested matRipple ancestors get launched, not only the the closest one" (#27213)

Issues.Title: bug(slider): Setting range slider value programmatically doesn't update the underlying DOM element
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

This is somewhat similar to an older issue with mat-checkbox (https://github.com/angular/components/issues/22149)

I want to ensure that the range in the slider is always greater than zero. E.g. if the "end" value is currently 9, then a user can only move the "start" thumb as high as 8.

I'm enforcing it by subscribing to `valueChanges` of the form controls associated with the slider input elements.

```
this.start.valueChanges.subscribe(() => {
  if (this.start.value >= this.end.value) {
    this.start.setValue(this.end.value - 1, { emitEvent: false });
  }
});
```
Even though the code above guarantees the form control values satisfy the constraint, the underlying DOM `input` element doesn't reflect the programmatic change from the `setValue` call.

A workaround I'm currently using is injecting the `input` elements (via `@ViewChild`) and setting its `.value` directly.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/benvwf-lmrtl4?file=src%2Fexample%2Fslider-range-example.ts
Steps to reproduce:
1. Drag the "start" thumb all the way to the right


### Expected Behavior

The "start" thumb stops at the "8" tick mark, never reaches the last "9".

### Actual Behavior

- The "start" thumb goes up to the "end" position ("9").
- The form control value (printed above the slider) shows "8" - out of sync with the actual thumb state in the DOM

### Environment

- Angular: 16
- CDK/Material: 16
- Browser(s): Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(slider): Setting range slider value programmatically doesn't update the underlying DOM element" (#27208)

Issues.Title: docs(material/theming): update typography tables to be consistent
Issues.Body:
This change updates the top table in the typography guide to be consistent with what's implemented and with the table further down the page. I used the Scale Categories from [M2's type documentation](https://m2.material.io/design/typography/the-type-system.html#type-scale) for the Descriptions, since the old descriptions were carry-overs from the pre-MDC version, and could be confusing / misleading in this context.  It seemed appropriate to pull from the Material spec for these.  The use of "Large body text" and "Medium body text" is meant to help bridge the gap to the eventual shift to M3, since those type levels equate to [M3's Large and Medium body text](https://m3.material.io/styles/typography/type-scale-tokens#d74b73c2-ac5d-43c5-93b3-088a2f67723d), respectively. 

I also tweaked the second table to give greater emphasis to the class names that match the typography levels when more than one class is mapped to a style.  I removed `mat-h5` and `mat-h6` from the second table, since they were explained in the section below the table and since they don't map directly to any type levels in the Material spec, their inclusion in this table alongside `headline-5/6` (with different meaning) could be confusing. 

Fixes #27112
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs(material/theming): update typography tables to be consistent" (#27206)

Issues.Title: Wrong checkbox checkmark color when palettes are set with CSS variables
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When defining palettes (accent or primary) with CSS variables, the chekmark color of mdc checkboxes is not the right one.

Indeed, on [this line](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/material/core/tokens/m2/mdc/_checkbox.scss#L13), `type-of($value) == 'color'` is always false when palettes are defined with CSS variables.
When palettes are defined directly with web or hex colors, the mdc checkbox chekmark color is correct.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create an Angular project with angular 16
2. Run the command `ng add  @angular/material @angular/cdk.`
3. Ad custom theme by defininng palette with CSS variables
4. Add material mdc checkbox to a template

You can reproduce the problem with [this demo on Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/bug-material-checkbox-qdtwuw).

### Expected Behavior

When color 500 of the accent palette is dark, the checkmark of the checkboxes must be white.

### Actual Behavior

When color 500 of the accent palette is define by a CSS variable, the checkmark of the checkboxes is always black in a light-theme.

### Environment

- Angular: v16.0.0
- CDK/Material: v16.0.1
- Browser(s): all
- Operating System : Ubuntu
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Wrong checkbox checkmark color when palettes are set with CSS variables " (#27204)

Issues.Title: bug(Stepper): interacted event object should contain index of step which is clicked.
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The interacted event should emit new index to detect whether stepper is going to next step or previous step.
The new Index variable is there in code but it is local variable. It should be global variable to be emitted in the event.
It will be helpful to detect whether stepper is going forward or backward by comparing newIndex and selectedIndex.
Or it will be helpful if you provide a property in event object which will determine whether the stepper is going forward or backward.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Interact with steps by clicking on it.
2. The interacted event object contains only selectedIndex in interactedStream._stepper.selectedIndex


### Expected Behavior

The interacted event object should contain index of step which is clicked.

### Actual Behavior

The interacted event object does not contain index of step which is clicked.

### Environment

- Angular: 14.0.7
- CDK/Material: 14.1.0
- Browser(s): Chrome: 113.0.5672.127
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(Stepper): interacted event object should contain index of step which is clicked." (#27199)
